alert.note: Alert for Central Interior; Deltana and Tanana Flats; Denali; Eastern Alaska Range; Middle Tanana Valley; Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued May 01 at 3:40PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks
info.description: ...Rising Water Levels and Ice Jam Potential on Interior Rivers... Spring breakup is picking up speed in the Middle Tanana Valley and across the Interior with the warm temperatures this past week and over the weekend. Significant melting of the snowpack was observed in the Fairbanks area and now that water is rapidly making its way into the waterways. Rivers and stream around Fairbanks continue to show significant rises on the gages that are not ice effected. Observers report that the Chena River is mainly open from the Steese Bridge to University Bridge in Fairbanks as well as several hundred yards upstream and down stream of the Moose Creek Dam with only small sheets of ice noted. Significant ice remains on the Chena and Little Chena near the Nordale Bridge. Ice on the Tanana River also remain mostly solid with a few small open leads. With the rising water levels the ice could lift at any time and move in sheets with the potential for ice dams to form. Residents should be vigilant if they are near rivers and streams and watch for rapidly rising water. Significant overflow continues on many of the waterways in the Interior. Local ponding of water in the urban areas will continue to be an issue. For the latest river information go to www.weather.gov/aprfc.
